DOCNAME: CASE OF VAN RAALTE v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 14;Violation of P1-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant is a GPE national born in DATE and resident in ORG . He has never been married and has no children .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Inspector of Direct Taxes sent the applicant an assessment of his contributions for DATE under various social security schemes , including ORG ( Algemene kinderbijslagwet , see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant filed an objection ( bezwaarschrift - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) to this assessment on CARDINAL DATE . He based his argument on LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG and on the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE ( Staatsblad ( Official Gazette ) no . CARDINAL ( " the royal decree " ) - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , by virtue of which unmarried childless women of DATE or over were exempted from the obligation to pay contributions under ORG ; in his view the prohibition of discrimination such as was contained in LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) implied that this exemption should be extended to men in the same situation .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant later received similar assessments for DATE , against which he likewise filed objections . The ORG reserved his decision on these , pending the outcome of the proceedings relating to the DATE assessment .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the ORG issued a decision declaring the first objection unfounded on the ground that " under national legislation the application of LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG is not possible since the person by whom the contributions are due is not female " .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant appealed to ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) on DATE . Relying on LAW taken together with LAW No . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL+PCARDINAL - CARDINAL ) and LAW , he claimed that the provisions of the royal decree should be given a " gender neutral " construction . LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG and the royal decree were in his view discriminatory .
The Inspector lodged a written defence . Thereafter the applicant filed a reply , and the ORG a rejoinder .

CARDINAL . ORG The exemption enjoyed by unmarried childless women of CARDINAL or over from the obligation to pay contributions under LAW was abolished by LAW of DATE ( Staatsblad DATE , no . CARDINAL ) , with effect from DATE .
CARDINAL . ORG gave its judgment on DATE , dismissing the applicant ’s appeal and confirming the ORG ’s decision . Its reasoning included the following :

" CARDINAL . Neither the wording of the impugned provision nor its drafting history indicates that the legislature intended to discriminate or has caused discrimination . In particular , it can not be said that the legislator wished to discriminate against unmarried men who had reached DATE before the beginning of the calendar year and were not entitled to child care benefits under LAW vis - à - vis comparable women .

CARDINAL . By means of the provision set out in LAW ( CARDINAL ) of ORG , the legislature merely wished to take due account of the difference in factual situation between women over DATE and men over DATE with regard to having ( begetting or raising ) children .

CARDINAL . The fact , as stated by [ the applicant ] , that it appears from statistical data that older men only rarely beget children makes no difference to what is considered in paragraph CARDINAL above . The legislature has assessed the factual situation of the group of women referred to in section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG differently on the basis of the possibility of their having children and not on the basis of the reality of their having children .
Older men ’s possibilities of procreating are fundamentally different from those of older women , in the sense that this difference is considerable irrespective of these statistical data .
CARDINAL . The difference in treatment opposed by [ the applicant ] is therefore not based on a difference in sex , but on a difference in factual situation .

This conclusion is not altered by the fact that this difference ( partly ) coincides with the difference between the sexes . The impugned provision does not therefore contravene the prohibition of discrimination .
CARDINAL . It can not be excluded in principle that the fairness and acceptability of ORG benefit by taking account of these differences in factual situation .
It not being for ORG to rule on the intrinsic value of a statute , the ORG can not consider whether the differences in factual situation entirely justify the exemption in question .
CARDINAL . Even if it were correct , contrary to what is set out above , that the impugned provision contravenes the prohibition of discrimination , this would not benefit [ the applicant ] .
ORG would not be at liberty to extend the exemption in question to CARDINAL or more groups of individuals for whom the legislature definitely did not intend it .
If the argument based on prohibition of discrimination should have to be accepted in principle , this could only lead to a finding that the impugned provision had no binding force .
This would not be in [ the applicant ’s ] interest . "

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant filed an appeal on points of law ( beroep in cassatie - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) to ORG ( PERSON ) on DATE . In so far as is relevant here , he challenged the above reasoning of ORG relying on LAW ( article CARDINAL ) and LAW .
The Inspector responded in writing .
CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the appeal on DATE . Its reasoning included the following :

" CARDINAL . The third ground of appeal [ middel ] argues that the principle set out in section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG violates LAW CARDINAL of the LAW article CARDINAL ) . To the extent that the ground of appeal relies on the latter provision ( article CARDINAL ) , it must fail as the present case does not relate to any of the rights and freedoms enumerated in the Convention .

CARDINAL . In view of , inter alia , the drafting history of the provision in question the limitation of the exemption set out in section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG to women of CARDINAL and over was inspired by the idea that it would not be reasonable to levy contributions under LAW from these women , since it had to be assumed that a great number of them would never have children and were prevented by social and - unlike men - biological factors from ever bearing children .

ORG need not consider the question of whether the above - mentioned fact constitutes an objective and reasonable justification for exempting only women of CARDINAL and over from paying contributions under LAW .

Since this difference in treatment between ( unmarried ) women and men , which in any case , given their biological differences , can not be said to lack all reasonable ground , has been removed with effect from DATE by the abolition of the exemption by LAW DATE ( PERSON , no . CARDINAL ) there is no reason for a court to intervene by declaring the exemption applicable , for DATE in question , to unmarried men of CARDINAL and over .
CARDINAL . ORG After the delivery of this judgment the Inspector issued decisions dismissing the applicant ’s objections to the assessments for DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . ORG According to figures published by ORG voor de Statistiek ) , the number of " legitimate " children born alive in the GPE to fathers aged DATE or over in DATE was CARDINAL , or PERCENT of the total number of " legitimate " children born DATE ( CARDINAL ) .
The corresponding figure for mothers aged DATE or over was CARDINAL , or CARDINAL per thousand .
No figures are available for children born out of wedlock .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the DATE LAW provides :

" All persons present in the GPE shall be treated in the same way in similar situations . Discrimination on the ground of religion , philosophical convictions , political leanings , race , sex , or any other ground whatsoever shall not be allowed . "
CARDINAL . ORG Under GPE constitutional law , courts may not review the constitutionality of statutes . Article CARDINAL reads :
" The courts shall not rule on the constitutionality [ grondwettigheid ] of statutes and treaties . "

Delegated legislation , on the other hand , may be examined to determine whether it conforms with the LAW and even with unwritten general principles of law ( see the judgment of ORG of DATE , Beslissingen in DATE ( Reports of Decisions in Taxation Cases - " BNB " ) DATE , no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW provides that provisions of international treaties and decisions of international ( intergovernmental ) organisations which , according to their content , may be binding on anyone shall have binding force after they have been published .
With regard to the prohibition of discrimination , the GPE is a party to , inter alia , LAW ( " the LAW " ) , LAW which provides as follows :

" All persons are equal before the law and are entitled without discrimination to the equal protection of the law . In this respect , the law shall prohibit any discrimination and guarantee to all persons equal and effective protection against discrimination on any ground such as race , colour , sex , language , religion , political or other opinion , national or social origin , property , birth or other status . "
CARDINAL . ORG was enacted in DATE .
Until DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , section CARDINAL of ORG provided as follows :
" CARDINAL . Contributions are due by :
( a ) every person by whom contributions are due by way of assessment under LAW ( PERSON ouderdomswet ) ;
CARDINAL . The first paragraph , under ( a ) , may be derogated from by royal decree , subject to conditions and limitations if need be , in respect of unmarried women who have reached DATE .
CARDINAL . ... "

Persons referred to in sub - paragraph ( a ) were all those who had not yet reached DATE and who were either GPE residents or , if not GPE residents , subject to ORG ) in respect of work carried out in the GPE under a contract of employment ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Any person who was either a GPE resident or subject to ORG in respect of work carried out in the GPE under a contract of employment was entitled to benefits under LAW for children for whose maintenance he or she was financially responsible , whether they were his or her own by birth or marriage or foster children ( sections DATE CARDINAL of ORG ) . Such entitlement was not subject to the condition that the person concerned had contributed to the scheme .

CARDINAL . ORG At the time of the events complained of , the derogation from the general rule made possible by LAW ( CARDINAL ) was provided for by the royal decree of CARDINAL DATE ( Staatsblad no . CARDINAL ) . Section CARDINAL provided :

" In derogation from section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( a ) of ORG , no contributions shall be due by an unmarried woman who has reached DATE before the beginning of the calendar year and who is not entitled to child care benefits under that LAW . "

CARDINAL . ORG recognised in its judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( PERSON ( GPE Law Reports - " GPE " ) DATE , no . CARDINAL ( corrected in GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL ) ) that LAW is a provision of an international treaty which , according to its content , may be binding on anyone , and must therefore in principle be applied directly by the GPE courts ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

However , in a number of judgments it has declined to construe LAW in such a way as to deprive national legislation of its effect even if it considered that a given measure constituted illegal discrimination between men and women , holding that , where various options were open to the national authorities to remove such discrimination , the choice should be left to the legislature in view of the social and legal implications attending each possible course of action ( see the judgments of ORG of DATE , GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL , and DATE , GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL ) .

In its judgment of DATE ( GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL ) , cited in ORG Right ’s PERSON and Others v. the GPE judgment of DATE ( Series A no . CARDINAL-C ) , ORG came to a similar finding with regard to LAW taken together with LAW loc . cit . , p. CARDINAL , para . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG ( Centrale PERSON ) - the administrative tribunal competent to decide most types of social - security disputes but not , inter alia , disputes relating to contributions due under ORG - has held that LAW is in principle directly applicable in the field of social security .

Thus , in its judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( PERSON ( Social Security Law Reports - " RSV " ) DATE , no . CARDINAL ) , ORG considered discriminatory the rule that to qualify for benefits under LAW ( DATE ) Benefits Act ( LANGUAGE uitkering vervolgingsslachtoffers DATE ) a married woman had to be a " breadwinner " whereas no such requirement applied to married men . In CARDINAL judgments delivered on DATE ( PERSON ( GPE Administrative Law Reports - " GPE " ) DATE , ORG . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) , it came to a similar finding with regard to LAW ( Algemene arbeidsongeschiktheidswet ) , but only with effect from DATE on which legislation entered into force that was intended to remove discrimination but which had failed to do so adequately .

Similarly , in its judgments of DATE ( NJCM - Bulletin CARDINAL , no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , and ORG , no . CARDINAL ) , it recognised the right of a widower to claim a widow ’s pension ( weduwenpensioen ) under the General Widows and Orphans Act ( PERSON weduwen- en wezenwet ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Contributions under LAW and certain other social - security schemes were levied by ORG in the same way as income tax ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the General Exceptional Medical Expenses Act ( Algemene wet bijzondere ziektekosten ) , declared applicable by analogy under LAW ) .
CARDINAL . ORG It was possible to file an objection against an assessment with the Inspector ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG Act - Algemene wet inzake rijksbelastingen ) .

An appeal against the ORG ’s decision lay to ORG ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of ORG ) . A further appeal could be filed on points of law to ORG ( section CARDINAL of LAW op de rechterlijke organisatie ) .

CARDINAL . ORG As noted above ( see paragraph CARDINAL ) , the possibility provided for under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) came to an end when LAW of DATE ( Staatsblad DATE , no . CARDINAL ) came into effect on DATE . Accordingly , on that date men and women became equally liable to pay contributions under ORG whatever their age and whether or not they were married or had children .
